N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 9 ยง 7201.5 - Intra-agency confidentiality

State Regulations
(a) No employee, agent or member of the commission or any member of the citizens'
policy and complaint review council or member of the medical review board shall
have access to health information relating to any identified person, including
confidential HIV-related information on any person, except in connection with
the following activities: (1)
investigation
into the death of any inmate pursuant to article 3 of the Correction

Law; (2)
investigation or
evaluation of health care in any correctional facility; (3)
monitoring and providing technical
assistance to any correctional facility or operator thereof; (4)
maintenance of statistical data as
authorized by law; (5)
research
studies approved by the commission; (6)
as necessary in the ordinary course of
business to provide legal services to the commission; and
(7)
as otherwise relevant and necessary to
carry out the express statutory functions, powers and duties of the
commission. (b) No
employee, agent, or member of the commission, or any member of the citizens'
policy and complaint review council or member of the medical review board, who
has access to confidential HIV-related information shall disclose such
information to any other person unless such person also has access to
confidential HIV-related information as described in this Part, section 7064 of
this Title, or as authorized by Public Health Law, article 27-F or its
implementing regulations. (c) Each
employee of the State Commission of Correction who is given authorized access
to the commission's records of an identified person that contain HIV-related
information shall: (1)
be advised in writing
that such person shall not: (i) examine
documents containing HIV-related information unless required to do so in the
course of his or her official duties; (ii)
remove or copy any such documents unless
he or she is acting within the scope of his or her assigned duties; or
(iii)
discuss the content of any
such documents with any person unless that person is authorized to have access
to such documents; (2)
sign a statement attesting that he or she has read the above restrictions and
stating that he or she understands that violation may lead to disciplinary
action, including suspension or dismissal from employment and that such
violation may be against New York State law and lead to arrest and criminal
prosecution. Notes
